719813f-c.title: Manhattan: Fort Washington Aven - Broadway
719813f-c.text:
Fort Washington Avenue, at Broadway, showing the Abbey Inn and
greenhouse.

View 2,3 show the florist's, above the Abbey Inn.

E. P. Chrystie  Februaty 3, 1924
View 1-3

717804f-a.text:
Broadway from, but not including, Fort Washington Avenue, to and including Dyckman Street. The frame house on the right and the brick house in the centre will be demolished around 1934, when all the land shown on the west side of Broadway will become part of the newly created Fort Tryon Park. On the east side, the first street seen is Nagle Avenue, with Sherman Avenue the next street north.
November 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
717804f-a.folder: Broadway & Fort Washington Avenue, Manhattan, NY

715702f-a.text:
570 West 159th Street, adjoining the S.E. corner of Broadway.
1932.
J. Clarence Davies Collection, Museum of the City of New York.
Negative No. 24

717757f-a.text:
The rear of a frame house on the west side of Broadway, north of Fort Washington Avenue. This house will be demolished in 1934 in the creation of Fort Tryon Park, when the northern section of Fort Washington Avenue, including its second intersection with Broadway, will be closed.
November 22, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
717757f-a.folder: Broadway & Fort Washington Avenue, Manhattan, NY

717758f-b.text:
Broadway, west side, just north of Fort Washington Avenue, showing the Atkins estate. The a ea was later built over with apartment houses.
E. P. Chrystie  June 16, 1923
